England herself. A still larger portion is so en-
cumbered with debts due to the merchants IN the
mother country, that mortgages are held there upon
almost all the crops, which are accordingly trans
mitted to England. In short, such is the weight
and pressure Of the debts due upon the plantations
that the income is drained to supply the English
creditor, and nothing remains for transportation
elsewhere than to the mother country. In conflr-
nation of this fact, we have the authority OF most
respectable American merchant who has been re-
siding in one Of West india Islands, and has re-
turned since the operation Of the act of Parliament
commenced. He states that op the 5th OF January,
1926, notice was given to the commanders OF seye-
raj American vessels then in port, that they would
be permitted 10 clear out for any part OF the world
EXCEPT Great Britain. Not one OF them made use
of the permission nor, he SAYS, would one OF them
during the year. And why not For the simple
reason that cargo cannot be procured for any 9th


er part of the world except Great Britain; and
there they cannot 20. Thus, then, it will be seen
that this great magnanimity on the part OF GIeat
Britain consists in rendering to us trade which
by the circumstances Of .thc colonies themselves is
la perfect nuity and requiring from us IN return
for such erfreme iiberality the enjoyment OF per-
feet and effective commerce. We trust that nell
ther the people nor the government of this country
will be gulled by so palpabe an artlfice. We re-
auire but fair and honorable recprocty we ask no


avor; we claim no privileges for which we are un
willing to give an equivalent; we would be will
ling TO sacrifice something to remove this bone OF
contention; but we would not submit to sacrifice the
dignity and honor of the country to accept the in
estimable oHer Of nu'luy as a boon journal.

From the NelO Fork Times.

II will be recollected that Mr.. Rush (Secretary
of the Treasury and Mr.. M'Lane Chairman OF
the Congressional Committee OF Ways and Mcans)
differed in their statements OF the amount appilca
Bile to the redemption of the public debt IN 1870
and 1927. The discrepancy was So,o4S, i9o-a
sum so enormous that it seemed to shake the Iaith
of the public in all financial calculations. The
enemies of Mr.. Rush made it a matter OF great
triumph relying upon the reputation OF Mr.. NJ
Lane, they took it for granted that the Secretary
was in error.


Mr.. Rush submitted in utter silence to their
injurious and unfounded imputations At last
however, the error is discovered to be in the report
of the Committee; and Mr.. M'Lane is forced to
acknowledge it. And then he complains that the
Secretary g exhibited too much sensitvcness when
expositions Of the state of the Treasury are made
This nsinuation, and the talk about the "tiourlsh
Of trumpets," may, may not, for any thing we
know, apply to those who successfully yncicated
the correctness of the Secretary's report; but to
apply such remarks to himself, when it was known
that he had in every way forborne to vindca,e
himself when he could have done it SO easily and
so trumphantly-is not exactly what might have
been expected from Mr.. MLane.


The notorious Fledericksburgh conventions, and
other members of the jackson Combination,' =
have attempted to raise an alarm about the state
of the Treasury. We see daily so many speci-
mems Of candor and fair dealing from the same
quarter, that we shall make no extra remarks
about that piece of imposition, but shall proceed
to state what the condition of the Treasury is, and
what it has been for the last eight years.
TREASURY OF THE UNITED STATES.

Friday, March 9-6, A. M.
II has become our painful task to record another
most destructive visitation Of our unfortunate town
by ire which broke out this morning, at half past
one o'clock, in small shell of building South side
OF Main street, few PAGES East of Church street
occupied as whcelwrisht shopby Mr.. E. Balance.


The building was in blaze before it was discover.
ed, and the tenants of the large frame house be-


longing to the heirs of David Patterson, forming
the ). r. corner of Main and Church street, were
not apprzed of their danger until the flames had
communicated to it, such was the rapidty Of their
progress owing to the dryness of the weather, and
a strong S. +. wind.


The buildings on the North side Of Main street.
Immediately opposite the fire, we're also very com
bustbe. The exertions Of the fire companies sue.
ceeded in preserving them. But it is beyond the
power OF our pen to describe the scene which pre-
sented itself when the flames had risen to their
height, in the second building. The wind, which
seemed to have increased in violence. whirled the
sparks and flakes of fire to an immense distance,
descended like drifting snow, which, literally COW
ering the shingled roofs of the houses to lecward
seemed to defy all human power to save them from
confagrat,on. Several times were some of the
most combustible OF them on fire, but as often ex-
hngulsheti by the active exertions of our hardy fire.
men. At length, it was perceived that fake had
lodged on the ample and elevated roof of Christ
Church, (about two hundred and fifty Yards to lee
ward Of the fre) and kindled into blaze. The hose
OF one OF the fire companies was Immediately sent
to extinguish it-but, alas too late. The FIRE had
penetrated into the vacancy between the yaulted
ceiling and the ridge pole, and there was no means
OF ascent within the church--the stream of water
could not reach it from without; and before lad
der of sufficient length could be obtained, the fire
had spread the whole length of the roof and burs!
forth IN terrific grandeur.


The buildings between Main street and the
church, within the parallels Of Church and Fen
Church streets, were now considered out of dam
ger; but those beyond the church, within the same
parallel it appeared to be beyond all human powes
to save The elegant mansion of Walter Heron
Esq. half mile, at least from the original seat Of
the fre, had caught about the same time, and in the
same manner as the Church. Believing his prem
lses IN no danger, Mr.. Heron had gone to render
ASSISTANCE to those who were Immediately threat
ened, as had all the people belonging to his extern
sive rope walk; and We are informed that there
was not a male person on the lot. We regret 70
add, that his house was burnt to the ground, and
but very little Of its valuable furniture saved.


The dwelling house and office belonging 70 B:
Pollard, Esq. onthe N. side of the Church., were,

When we are awlully told by the President lent !,
the United States, that he will be compelled undS "
certain circumstances, by an obligation 6 Sss evss
higher than that of human authority,s to use ba
ss military arm' of the Union to prevent the on
forcement of a law of State, passed under 1s
guarantee Of treaty Of the Union, solemny ,atf.
ed and promulgated as the supreme law Of tbs
land, by the proper authorities whereby rights have
been vested in the State which no human autbor;ts
can divest it of, but by the strong arm Of power.
when the Executive Of the State tells US that H.
will resist to the utmost any military attack which
the Government of the United States shall thinI
proper to make on the territory, the People, or ii,
sovereignty Of Georgia"-it is, indeed, time ta
stand upon our defence; and having asserted our
rights, to prepare to maintain them. We will not
then, wait for further orders.


The Colonels under my command will, there
fore, forthwith have their regiments in the best pos
sbe attitude of readiness to meet the worst STATE
of things which may grow out Of any attempt to
prevent the right to pursue the ends for which our
Government was instituted; to establish the sOy.
ereignty and independence Of the States, and pro.
mote the welfare and happiness of the People.
ED. HARDEN.

This statement goes upon the admission of Mr..
Flames notion of the law, that the unapplied
balances still continue as outstanding charges.
| There is another part of this matter which
seems to claim some notice that is the attempt
which was made by MIR. M'Lane and the opposi,
tion party. to establish new doctrine in regard
to the Sinking fund.- which certainly might occasion
some embarrassment at the Treasury. They con-
tended that the unapplied balances Of the Sinking
fund of any one year should continue, without
limitation, to be charges upon the Treasury until
redeemed. Mr.. Sprague refuted this assumption
in the cearest manner. He showed that the prac-
tice of Mr.. Crawford had been to carry the unap-
piled balances of the Sinking fund into the Ways
and Means of succeeding years; that a proper
construction Of the acts of l795, 1902 and 1917,
warranted him in doing so; and that there could
be no reason for throwing upon the treasury now,
the charges which properly belonged only to the
period OF MIR. Monroe's administration. hut adopt
what construction may, it is demonstrabe, and
was even admitted by Mr.. M'Lane, that the Trea-
! sufy is in more unembarrassed condition than it
has been at any time during the last seven years.
Such is the result of clear head, honestly and
! laborousy directed to the important ard difficult
duty Of experimenting the Treasury. We are
not little gratitied that truth, demonstrated by
figures, enables US thus clearly to manifest the





man Mr.. Rush.


We should be glad to see the National Gazette,
and other Journals who followed in the wake of
Mr. M'Lane, do as that gentleman has done, ac-
knowledge their error, and do justice to the head
OF the Treasury department. 1t is, we fear, in
vain to hope for justice from little minds they
mug their errors. Dem. Press.
Virginia Senator.-It seems that Mr.. TYLER.
| the newly elected Senator from Virginia, some
time since expressed his opinion that Mr.. Clay
acted correctly in supporting Mr. Adams and accep-
ting the office OF Secretary of State. The disclosure
of this fact has filled the Jacksonians with horror
and overwhelmed them with dismay; and, as is
their custom, they have denounced Mr. Tyler in
the most opprobrous terms. They accuse him of
gross deception and duplicity in the language he
held during the Senatorial canvass. For my part.
can perceive nothing of this. Mr.. Tyler may
respect Mr.. Adams and Mr.. Clay, and yet be op-
posed to their great leading measures This, how.
ever, does not satisfy the Jack sonians.


man must hate and vilify both Mr.. Adams
and MIR. Clay personally, before he can find favor
In the eyes OF the present opposition.


| am not surprised that this kind OF rancour
should exist only marvel that it should be
avowed. 1 can inform those furious politicians
that it is bad policy in them to denounce Mr.. ~
Ter upon this ground. They do not yet know to
Whoth tHis ue enuhclatioh may extend. What would
these hot theads say, should it be found that Louis
M'Lane of Delaware, and P. p. Barbour. of yir-
slnla, both stand in the same predicament with
MIR. Tyler? | have good reason to believe that
such is the fact.-Editor Of the Cinsannati Gas.

sum so enormous that it seemed to shake the Iaith
of the public in all financial calculations. The
enemies of Mr.. Rush made it a matter OF great
triumph relying upon the reputation OF Mr.. NJ
Lane, they took it for granted that the Secretary
was in error.


Mr.. Rush submitted in utter silence to their
injurious and unfounded imputations At last
however, the error is discovered to be in the report
of the Committee; and Mr.. M'Lane is forced to
acknowledge it. And then he complains that the
Secretary g exhibited too much sensitvcness when
expositions Of the state of the Treasury are made
This nsinuation, and the talk about the "tiourlsh
Of trumpets," may, may not, for any thing we
know, apply to those who successfully yncicated
the correctness of the Secretary's report; but to
apply such remarks to himself, when it was known
that he had in every way forborne to vindca,e
himself when he could have done it SO easily and
so trumphantly-is not exactly what might have
been expected from Mr.. MLane.


The notorious Fledericksburgh conventions, and
other members of the jackson Combination,' =
have attempted to raise an alarm about the state
of the Treasury. We see daily so many speci-
mems Of candor and fair dealing from the same
quarter, that we shall make no extra remarks
about that piece of imposition, but shall proceed
to state what the condition of the Treasury is, and
what it has been for the last eight years.

full articles.headline:
AWFUL FIRE AT NORFOLK /!
HERALD OFFICE, NORFOLK,
full articles.article:
Friday, March 9-6, A. M.
II has become our painful task to record another
most destructive visitation Of our unfortunate town
by ire which broke out this morning, at half past
one o'clock, in small shell of building South side
OF Main street, few PAGES East of Church street
occupied as whcelwrisht shopby Mr.. E. Balance.


The building was in blaze before it was discover.
ed, and the tenants of the large frame house be-


longing to the heirs of David Patterson, forming
the ). r. corner of Main and Church street, were
not apprzed of their danger until the flames had
communicated to it, such was the rapidty Of their
progress owing to the dryness of the weather, and
a strong S. +. wind.


The buildings on the North side Of Main street.
Immediately opposite the fire, we're also very com
bustbe. The exertions Of the fire companies sue.
ceeded in preserving them. But it is beyond the
power OF our pen to describe the scene which pre-
sented itself when the flames had risen to their
height, in the second building. The wind, which
seemed to have increased in violence. whirled the
sparks and flakes of fire to an immense distance,
descended like drifting snow, which, literally COW
ering the shingled roofs of the houses to lecward
seemed to defy all human power to save them from
confagrat,on. Several times were some of the
most combustible OF them on fire, but as often ex-
hngulsheti by the active exertions of our hardy fire.
men. At length, it was perceived that fake had
lodged on the ample and elevated roof of Christ
Church, (about two hundred and fifty Yards to lee
ward Of the fre) and kindled into blaze. The hose
OF one OF the fire companies was Immediately sent
to extinguish it-but, alas too late. The FIRE had
penetrated into the vacancy between the yaulted
ceiling and the ridge pole, and there was no means
OF ascent within the church--the stream of water
could not reach it from without; and before lad
der of sufficient length could be obtained, the fire
had spread the whole length of the roof and burs!
forth IN terrific grandeur.


The buildings between Main street and the
church, within the parallels Of Church and Fen
Church streets, were now considered out of dam
ger; but those beyond the church, within the same
parallel it appeared to be beyond all human powes
to save The elegant mansion of Walter Heron
Esq. half mile, at least from the original seat Of
the fre, had caught about the same time, and in the
same manner as the Church. Believing his prem
lses IN no danger, Mr.. Heron had gone to render
ASSISTANCE to those who were Immediately threat
ened, as had all the people belonging to his extern
sive rope walk; and We are informed that there
was not a male person on the lot. We regret 70
add, that his house was burnt to the ground, and
but very little Of its valuable furniture saved.


The dwelling house and office belonging 70 B:
Pollard, Esq. onthe N. side of the Church., were,

full articles.headline:
THE UNITED STATES AND GEORGrA
FROM THE SAVANNAH aEpuDLicAN, rEp. "a.


BRIGADE ORDERS
full articles.article:
IT. @. Sauannah, 24h Fsb.. 1aez


When we are awlully told by the President lent !,
the United States, that he will be compelled undS "
certain circumstances, by an obligation 6 Sss evss
higher than that of human authority,s to use ba
ss military arm' of the Union to prevent the on
forcement of a law of State, passed under 1s
guarantee Of treaty Of the Union, solemny ,atf.
ed and promulgated as the supreme law Of tbs
land, by the proper authorities whereby rights have
been vested in the State which no human autbor;ts
can divest it of, but by the strong arm Of power.
when the Executive Of the State tells US that H.
will resist to the utmost any military attack which
the Government of the United States shall thinI
proper to make on the territory, the People, or ii,
sovereignty Of Georgia"-it is, indeed, time ta
stand upon our defence; and having asserted our
rights, to prepare to maintain them. We will not
then, wait for further orders.


The Colonels under my command will, there
fore, forthwith have their regiments in the best pos
sbe attitude of readiness to meet the worst STATE
of things which may grow out Of any attempt to
prevent the right to pursue the ends for which our
Government was instituted; to establish the sOy.
ereignty and independence Of the States, and pro.
mote the welfare and happiness of the People.
ED. HARDEN.
Brig. Gen. 1st Brig. Georgia Militia.

full articles.article:
1927 excess 2,0OO,5S8 2,242767 242,a


This statement goes upon the admission of Mr..
Flames notion of the law, that the unapplied
balances still continue as outstanding charges.
| There is another part of this matter which
seems to claim some notice that is the attempt
which was made by MIR. M'Lane and the opposi,
tion party. to establish new doctrine in regard
to the Sinking fund.- which certainly might occasion
some embarrassment at the Treasury. They con-
tended that the unapplied balances Of the Sinking
fund of any one year should continue, without
limitation, to be charges upon the Treasury until
redeemed. Mr.. Sprague refuted this assumption
in the cearest manner. He showed that the prac-
tice of Mr.. Crawford had been to carry the unap-
piled balances of the Sinking fund into the Ways
and Means of succeeding years; that a proper
construction Of the acts of l795, 1902 and 1917,
warranted him in doing so; and that there could
be no reason for throwing upon the treasury now,
the charges which properly belonged only to the
period OF MIR. Monroe's administration. hut adopt
what construction may, it is demonstrabe, and
was even admitted by Mr.. M'Lane, that the Trea-
! sufy is in more unembarrassed condition than it
has been at any time during the last seven years.
Such is the result of clear head, honestly and
! laborousy directed to the important ard difficult
duty Of experimenting the Treasury. We are
not little gratitied that truth, demonstrated by
figures, enables US thus clearly to manifest the





man Mr.. Rush.


We should be glad to see the National Gazette,
and other Journals who followed in the wake of
Mr. M'Lane, do as that gentleman has done, ac-
knowledge their error, and do justice to the head
OF the Treasury department. 1t is, we fear, in
vain to hope for justice from little minds they
mug their errors. Dem. Press.
Virginia Senator.-It seems that Mr.. TYLER.
| the newly elected Senator from Virginia, some
time since expressed his opinion that Mr.. Clay
acted correctly in supporting Mr. Adams and accep-
ting the office OF Secretary of State. The disclosure
of this fact has filled the Jacksonians with horror
and overwhelmed them with dismay; and, as is
their custom, they have denounced Mr. Tyler in
the most opprobrous terms. They accuse him of
gross deception and duplicity in the language he
held during the Senatorial canvass. For my part.
can perceive nothing of this. Mr.. Tyler may
respect Mr.. Adams and Mr.. Clay, and yet be op-
posed to their great leading measures This, how.
ever, does not satisfy the Jack sonians.


man must hate and vilify both Mr.. Adams
and MIR. Clay personally, before he can find favor
In the eyes OF the present opposition.


| am not surprised that this kind OF rancour
should exist only marvel that it should be
avowed. 1 can inform those furious politicians
that it is bad policy in them to denounce Mr.. ~
Ter upon this ground. They do not yet know to
Whoth tHis ue enuhclatioh may extend. What would
these hot theads say, should it be found that Louis
M'Lane of Delaware, and P. p. Barbour. of yir-
slnla, both stand in the same predicament with
MIR. Tyler? | have good reason to believe that
such is the fact.-Editor Of the Cinsannati Gas.

where ne swingled it, TO a third, where with his

hung himself in his own barn.

ing term Of those offices.
